fact: The ISS has an average orbit height of 408km, but unless it's directly above we still have a long ways to go!
usFact: The ISS has an average orbit height of 254 miles, but unless it's directly above we still have a long ways to go!

fact: Mercury-Atlas 6, the first American orbital spaceflight, launched on February 20, 1962.
After three orbits the spacecraft re-entered Earth's atmosphere, landing in the North Atlantic Ocean. The mission flight time was 4 hours 55 minutes and 23 seconds.
Aboard Friendship 7, John Glenn became the first person to orbit the Earth.
alt: Astronaut John H. Glenn Jr. during the Mercury-Atlas 6 spaceflight.
title: Image by Nasa

fact: Spaceflight technology has come a long way since then. On November 2 2000, the first long-term residents arrived aboard the ISS.
The ISS has been continously occupied since that date hosting astronauts, engineers, scientists, and even space tourists.
So far 240 individuals from 19 countries have visited the International Space Station.
2020 marks the 20th anniversary of the International Space Station.
alt: A Nasa illustrated poster of Snoopy in space, celebrating the ISS 20th anniversary.
title: Image by Nasa

fact: Snoopy is the astronauts' personal safety mascot.
The ISS's massive solar arrays provide power to the station most of the time...
The solar array wingspan is 73m, 8m longer than a Boeing 777's.
usFact: The solar array wingspan is 240ft, 26ft longer than a Boeing 777's.

fact: but every orbital cycle, the station is eclipsed by the Earth for 35 minutes.
The International Space Station's main solar arrays drape across the Earth above the Pacific Ocean west of Hawaii.
alt: The International Space Station's main solar arrays over Earth.
title: Image by Nasa

fact: During the eclipse, external chemical batteries power the station. These batteries have limited lifespans and need to be replaced eventually.
Crewmembers sometimes partake in dangerous EVA (extravehicular activity) spacewalks, leaving the pressurized interior to make sure the station is never without power.
Astronauts and cosmonauts have conducted more than 221 spacewalks (and counting) for space station construction, maintenance and upgrades since December 1998.
A visualization of the ISS orbit from 14 September 2018 to 14 November 2018.
alt: A visualization ISS orbit from 14 September 2018 to 14 November 2018.
title: Image by Nasa

fact: The ISS travels an equivalent distance to the Moon and back in about a day.
Loss of power is just one of the many threats crewmembers face. The low altitude in which the ISS orbits is also home to a variety of space debris.
At 6430km, we've traveled the length of the Great Wall of China!
usFact: At 3995 miles, we've traveled the length of the Great Wall of China!

fact: Debris large enough to destroy the station can be easily tracked, while smaller objects that escape the optical and radar instruments can cause serious damage.
This image shows the potential damage a 7 gram object can do while traveling at the orbital velocity of the ISS.
title: Image by U.S. Military / Department of Defense

fact: Despite the unforgiving environment, the ISS is home to our most important microgravity labs.
Research is conducted in a variety of fields: astrobiology, astronomy, physical sciences, materials science, space weather, meteorology, and even space medicine.
More than 3 million lines of software code on the ground support more than 1.5 million lines of flight software code.
The most notable ISS experiment is the Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer (AMS-02), which is instrumental in the detection of dark matter.
Currently docked on the station, the AMS-02 would have required too much bandwidth and power to operate as it's own satellite.
This composite image, made from six frames, shows the International Space Station, with a crew of five onboard, in silhouette as it transits the Sun.
alt: Image composite showing the ISS traveling past the sun.
title: Image by Nasa

fact: Medical research on the ISS helps us understand the affects of space environments on the human body. Knowledge of space medicine is crucial to our future goals of long-term space travel and space colonisation.
Through Expedition 58, the microgravity laboratory has hosted more than 2,700 research investigations from researchers in more than 103 countries.
Comet Lovejoy photographed by Expedition 30 commander Dan Burbank.
alt: Comet Lovejoy, as seen in space.
title: Image by Nasa/Dan Burbank

fact: Because of its modular design, the ISS is incredibly accomodating to equipment and lab additions.
More than 20 different research payloads can be hosted outside the station at once, including Earth sensing equipment, materials science payloads, and particle physics experiments.

alt: Diagram of ISS structure and modules
title: Image by Nasa

fact: Four different cargo spacecraft deliver science, cargo and supplies: Northrop Grumman’s Cygnus, SpaceX’s Dragon, JAXA’s HTV, and the Russian Progress.
Up to six spacecraft can be docked at the ISS at any given time.
Earth is 12,742km wide, meaning the ISS is currently on the other side of the world!
usFact: Earth is 7,917 miles wide, meaning the ISS is currently on the other side of the world!
